titleStmt.title: Middleton, Thomas, d. 1627 : : Your five gallants [1608]

editionStmt.p: This electronic version was produced at the Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing at the University of Newcastle by keyboarding from a microfilm printout of an early printed version. It was originally in a format devised in the Centre, with reference panels at the beginning of each line, known as "LILAC". It was subsequently converted by an automated process to a TEI XML format. It lacks the speaker tags provided in the copytext. Contractions and variant spellings of function words have been silently regularised. The text thus lacks information about the original forms of many words and expressions.

publicationStmt.publisher: Thomas Middleton, d. 1627 (1580-1627) Your fiue Gallants. As it hath beene often in Action at the Black-friers. Written by T. Middleton London Imprinted for Richard Bonian [etc.] [1608]

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Your five gallants. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1608? Date first performed: 1607.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Frippery/Broker Gallant Goldstone/Cheating Gallant Primero/Bawd Gallant Pursnet/Pocket Gallant Tailby/Whore Gallant Master Fitzgrave Pyamont Bungler 2nd fellow Vintner Arthur Fulk Jack Marmaduke Katherine Mistress New-cut Novice Drawer Hymn 1 Curtesan 2 Curtesan 3 Curtesan letter/reported voice 4 Curtesan Fellow 2 fellow 3 fellow 4 fellow Boy Tailor one bringing clothes 1 gentleman 2 gentleman another bringing clothes constable combined voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

stage.l: Presenter or prologue, passing over the Stage, the Bawd gallant,
with three wenches gallantly attired, meets him, the whore gallant,
the peacheocket-Gallant, the cheating gallant, kiss these three
wenches and depart in a little whisper and wanton action: now
for the other the broker gallant, he sits at home yet I warrant
you, at this time of day, summing up

sp.l: Is your pawn good and sound sir?
I will pawn my life for that sir;
Place yourself there then, I will seek to prefer it presently:
my Master is very jealous of the pestilence; marry the
pox sits at meat and meal with him.
Lent the fifth day of September to mistress Onset upon
her gown, Taffeta petticoat with three broad silver Laces,
three pound fifteen shillings.
Lent to Justice Cropshin upon both his Velvet Jackets, five
pound ten shillings.
Lent privately to my Lady New-cut, upon her gilt Casting bottle,
and her silver Lie-pot, fifty five shillings.
Sir.
Lent to Sir Oliuer Needy upon his Taffeta cloak, Beaver
hat, and perfumed leather jerkin, 6 pound 5. shillings.
May it please your worship --
Lent to master Andrew Lucifer, upon his flame coloured
doublet, and blue Taffeta hose -- top the candle sirrah, methinks
the light burns blue -- when came that suite in.
It has lain above the year now?
Fire and brimstone, cut it out into matches, the white linings
will serve for tinder.
And with little help sir, they are almost
black enough
already? -- Sir here is another
come with a pawn;
Keep him aside awhile and reach me hither the Bill
of the last week;
It is here at hand sir?
Now sir what is your pawn?
The second part of a Gentlewoman's gown sir, the lower
half I mean;
I apprehend you easily, the breeches of the gown!
Very proper, for she wears the doublet at home, a
guest that lies in my house sir;
she looks every hour: for her
cousin out of the country.
O her cousin lies here she may mistake in that? my
friend of what is your pawn?
Parish why? Saint Clements sir, -- I will come to you presently,
What parish is your pawn my friend, Saint Brides five
Saint Dunstones none; Saint Clements 3. 3, at Clements, away
with your pawn sir, your parish is infected, I will neither purchase
the plague for six pence in the pound, and a groat Bill
money, nor venture my small stock into contagious parishes: you
have your answer fare you well, as fast as you can sir.
The pox arrest you sir at the suite of the Suburbs.
Aye welcome, welcome.
For I think plague scorns your company.
I rank with chief Gallants, I love to smell safely:
lent in the vacation to master Proctor upon his Spiritual
gown, five angels; and upon his Corporal doublet, fifteen shillings.
sum three pound five shillings.
Sir.
Now sir.

stage.l: Enter his man bringing a trunk.

sp.l: Here is one come in with a trunk of apparel.
Whence comes it?
From Saint Martins in the field, -- Saint Mary Maudlin 2.
Saint Martins none, here is an honest fellow, let him appear sir.
You may come near sir,
O welcome, welcome, what is your pawn sir?
Faith a Gentlewoman's whole suite sir.
Whose suite? it is well.
A poor kind soul, troubled with a bad husband; one
that puts her to her shifts here.
He puts her from her shifts methinks when she is
fain to pawn her clothes?
Look you sir, a fair Satin gown; new Taffeta petticoat.
Stay, this petticoat has been turned?
Often turned up and down if you will,
but never turned sir.
Cry you mercy indeed:
A fine white Beaver, pearl band; three falls, I have known her
have more in her days.
Alas if she be but a Gentlewoman of any count
or charge, three falls are nothing, in these days --
Know that; tut
the world is changed, gentlewoman's faults stand upright now,
no sin but has a Bolster, that it may lie at ease: Well what do
you borrow of these sir?
Twelve pound if you will sir.
How?
They were not hers for twenty.
Why so: our pawn is ever
thrice the value of our money
unless in plate and Jewels, how should the months be restored
and the use else? we must cast it for the twelve month, so
many pounds, so many months, so many eighteen pence,
then the use of these eighteen pence, then the want of the
return of those pounds, all these must be laid together, which
well considered, the valuation of the pawn had need to
sound treble: Can six pound pleasure the Gentlewoman.
It may please her, but like a man of threescore in the
Limberest degree.
I have but one word more to say in it, twenty nobles is
all and the utmost that I will hazard upon it.
she must be content with it, the less borrowed the better paid, come.
Arthur?
At hand sir.
Tell out twenty nobles, and take her name in a Bill?
I am satisfied sir?
Welcome: good Saint Martins in the field, welcome,
welcome, I know no other name?
What so hard at your prayers?
A little sir, summing up my pawns here: what Master Primero?
is it you sir Gallant; and how does all the pretty sweet
Ladies, those plump, kind, delicate blisses; ha? whom I kiss in
my very thoughts: how do they Gallant?
Why Gallant? if they should not do well in my house,
where should it be done boy, have I not a glorious Situation?
O a Gallant Receipt, Violet air, curious garden, quaint
walks, fantastical Arbours, three backdoors and a Coach gate,
nay thou art admirably seated, little furniture will serve
thee, thou art never without movables.
I praise my Stars; ah the goodly virginities that have
been cut up in my house, and the goodly patrimonies that
have lain like sops in the gravy, and when those sops were
eaten, yet the meat was kept whole for another, and another,
and another, for as in one pie twenty may dip their sippets, so
upon one woman forty may consume their patrimonies.
Excellent, master Primero?
Well, I will pray for women while I live,
they are the profitablest
fools, I will say that for them,
a man can keep about his house
the prettiest kind fowl, so tame, so gentle
even to strangers, hands,
So soon familiar, suffer to be touched,
Of those they never saw twice:
the Dove is not like them.
Most certain, for that is honest; but I have a suite to you?
And so have I to you.
That happens well,
Grant mine and I will grant yours?
A match.
Make me perfect in that trick that
got you so much at
Primero.
O for the thread tied at your partners leg: the twitch?
Aye that twitch if you call it so.
That secret twitch got me five hundred pound,
Ere it was first known, and since I have sold it well
Five hundred pound laid down shall not yet buy,
The fee simple of my twitch I would be here with it,
It was a blessed invention, I had been a beggar many a lousy year
But for my twitch. It was the prettiest twitch?
Many overcheated gulls, have fatted
Me with the bottom of their patrimonies
Even to the last Sop,
gaped while I fed them;
who now live by that Art that first undid them.
But I must swear you to be secret, close,
As a maid, at Ten,
Had you sworn but two years higher I would
never have believed you.
Nay I let twelve alone,
For after twelve has struck, maids look for one.
I look for one too and a maid I think.
What, to come hither?
Sure she follows me? a pretty fat eyed wench, with a
Venus in her cheek, did but Raiment smile
upon her, she were
Nectar for great Dons, boy and that is my suite to thee.
And that is granted already: of what volume is this
book, that I may fit a cover to it?
Faith neither in folio, nor in
Decimo sexto, but in Octauo
between both, a pretty middle sized trug.
Then I have fitted her already: in my eye ifaith: here
came a pawn in even now will
make shift to serve her as fit,
look you sir Gallants, Satin, Taffeta, Beaver, fall and all.
Is it new.
New? you see it bears her youth as freshly, --
A pretty suite of clothes ifaith; -- but put case the
party should come to redeem them of a sudden?
Puh then your wit is sickly, have not I the policy think
you to seem extreme busy and defer
them till the morrow, against
which time that pawn shall be secretly fetched home,
and another carried out to supply the place.
I like thy craft well there.
A general course, o Frippery is an unknown benefit
sir Gallant!
And what must I give you for the hire now ifaith.
Of the whole suite, for the month?
Aye for the month.
Go to, you shall give me but twelve pence a day, Master
Primero you are a friend, and I will use you
so, it is got up at your
house in an afternoon ifaith, the hire of the whole month: ye
must think I can distinguish spirits and put a difference between
you and others: you pay no more ifaith.
I could have offered you no less, myself.
Tut, a man must use a friend, as a friend may use him;
your house has been a sweet house to me, both for pleasure
and profit: I will give you your due,
ommne tulit punctum, you
have always kept fine punks in your house,
that is for pleasure,
and I have had sweet pawns from
them, that is for profit now?
You flatter, you flatter sir Gallant? but whilst, here she
enters; I prithee question her? o you are welcome.
Is this your new scholar Master Primero?
Marry is she sir.
I will commend your judgment in a wench while I live,
that face will get money ifaith,
it will be a get penny I warrant
you? go to? your fortune was choice pretty Bliss to fall into
the regard of so kind a Gentleman.
I hope so sir.
See, what his care has provided already for you, you will be
simply set out to the world: if you will
have that care now to deserve
his pains o that will be acceptable: and these be the Rudiments
you must chiefly point at: to counterfeit cunningly, to
wind in gentlemen with powerful attraction, to keep his
house in name and custom, to dissemble with
your own brother,
never to betray your
fellows imperfections, nor lay open
the state of their bodies to strangers,
to believe those that give
you, to gull those that believe you,
to laugh at all under Taffeta,
and these be your rudiments.
There is even all ifaith,
we will trouble you with no more, nay
you shall live at ease enough:
for nimming away jewels and favours
from Gentlemen (which are your chief vails) hope that
will come naturally enough to you,
I need not instruct you, you will
have that wit, I trust to make the most of your pleasure.
I hope ones mother wit will serve for that sir.
O properest of all wench: it must be a she wit that does
those things, and thy mother was quick
enough at in her days.
Give me leave sister to examine you upon 2. or 3. particulars:
and you make you ready be not ashamed, here is none but
friends -- are you a maid.
Yes, in the last quarter sir.
Very proper, that is even
going out, a maid in the last
quarter, that is a whore in the first;
-- let me see, new moon on
Thursday, she will be changed by that
time too; are you willing
to pleasure gentlemen?
We are all born to pleasure our country forsooth.
Excellent, can you carry yourself cunningly, and seem
often holy.
O fear not that sir, my friends were all puritans.
I will never try her further.
She is done well ifaith, I fear not now to turn her loose
to any gentleman in Europe.
You need not sir of her own
accord, I think she will be
loose enough without turning -- Arthur.
Here sir.
Go make haste, shift her into that suite presently.
It shall be done.
Arthur do it neatly Arthur?
Fear it not sir.
Follow him wench.
With all my heart sir -- .
But master
In what are we forgetful all this while?
In what?
The wooing business man.
Heart that is true.
The Gallants will prevent us.
Are you certain.
I can avouch it there is a general meeting, at the deceased
knights house this afternoon there is
No doubt in that?
Would either thou or I might bear her from them.
My hopes are not yet faint.
Nor mine.
Tut man? nothing in women's hearts sooner win place,
than a brave outside and an impudent face?
And for both those we will fit it.
Aye if the devil be not in it, make haste:
I follow straight, vanish thou Fog, and Sink
beneath our brightness,
Abashed at the splendour of such beams:
We scorn thee, base eclipser of our glories,
That wouldst have hid our shine from mortals eyes,
Now Gallants, I am for you, aye and perhaps before you?
You can appear but glorious from yourselves,
And have your beams but drawn from
your own light,
But mine from many, many make me bright.
Here is a diamond that sometimes gracest the finger of a countess,
here sits a Ruby that near lines blushing for the Party
that pawned it: here a Sapphire, O providence and fortune!
my beginning was so poor, I would fain forget it, and I take
the only course, for I scorn to think on it. Slave to a trencher:
observer of a saltcellar, privy to nothing, but a close-stool, or
such unsavoury secret: but as I strive to forget the days of my
serving, so I shall once remember the first step of my raising,
for having hardly raked five mark together,
I rejoiced so in that
small stock, which most providently I ventured by water to
Blackwall, among fishwives, and in small time, what by weekly
return, and gainful restitution it rise to a great body, beside
a dish of fish for a present, that stately preserved me a
seven-night: nor ceased it there but drew on greater profit, for
I was held religious by those that do profess like abstinence,
and was full often secretly supplied, by charitable Catholics,
Who censured me sincerely obstinate, when merely I for hunger
nor for Zeal, eat up the fish, and put their alms to use! ha,
ha ha; but those times are run out, and for my sake, zealous
dissemblance has since fared the worse; -- let me see now,
whose cloak shall I wear today to continue change,
O -- Arthur.
Here sir.
Bring down sir Oliuer Needies Taffeta cloak. and Beaver
hat, I am sure he is fast enough?
and Andrew Lucifers Rapier and
dagger, in the knights ward, with the embossed girdle and hangers,
for he is in his third sweat by this time, sipping of the doctors
bottle, or picking the ninth part of a Rack of mutton dry
roasted, with a leash of nightcaps on his head like the popes
triple crown, and as many pillows crushed to his back, with
o the needles, for he got the pox of a Seamster, and it pricked so
much more naturally, -- quick Arthur quick, now,
To the deceased knights daughter
whom many Gallants sue to,
I amongst many: for
Since impudence gains more respect than virtue,
And coin them blood which few can now deny,
who are your chief Gallants, than but such as I.

stage.l: Enter Misters Katherine with Fitsgraue a Gentleman.

sp.l: You do your Beauties injury, sweet virgin,
To loose the time they must rejoice in youth:
There is no perfection in a woman placed
But wastes itself though it be never wasted,
Then judge your wrongs yourself.
Good Master Fitsgraue?
Through sorrow for the knight my fathers death,
(Whose being was the perfections of my joy:
And crown of my desires,) I cannot yet,
But forcedly, on marriage fix my heart,
Yet heaven forbid I should deject your hopes
Conceive not of me so uncharitably,
I should belie my soul if I should say,
You are the man I never should affect:
I understand you thus far, you are a Gentleman
Whom your estate and virtues may command
To a far worthier breast, than this of mine,
O cease, I dare not hear such blasphemy,
What is without you worthy, I neglect,
In you is placest the worth that I respect:
Vouchsafe unequalled Virgin whereon I justly kept,
Accept this worthless favour from your
servants arm, the hallowed beads,
The true and perfect number of my sighs.
Mine cannot equal yours, yet in exchange,
accept and wear it for my sake.
Even as my I will rate it?
Heart? Fitsgraue in such bosom single loves?

stage.l: Enter five Gallants at the farther door.

sp.l: So close, and private with her?
Observe them, he grows proud and bold?
Why was not this a general meeting?
By her own consent,
Death how I could taste his
blood?
See, the gentlemen, at my request do all present
themselves?
Manifold blisses wait on her desire,
whose beauty and whose mind so many honour?
I take your wishes thankfully? -- kind gentlemen!
all here assembled, over whose long suites,
I near insulted,
Not like that common sickness of our sex,
Grew proud in the abundance of my suitors,
Or number of the days they sued unto me.
Dutiful sorrow for my fathers death,
Not wilful coyness hath my hours detained
So long in silence:
I am left to mine own choice,
so much the more
My care calls on me If I err through love,
It is I must chide myself, I cannot shift
The fault unto my parents, they are at rest,
And I shall sooner err through love, than wealth.
Good.
Excellent.
That likes me well?
Hope still.
And my affections do pronounce you all
Worthy their pure and most entire deserts,
Yet they can choose but one,
Nor do I dissuade any of his hopes,
(Because my heart is not yet thoroughly fixed,
On marriage, or the man,)
But crave the quiet respite of one month,
The month unto this night, against which time,
I do invite you all to that election,
Which on my unstained faith, and Virgin promise,
Shall light amongst no strangers, but yourselves:
May this content you?
Glad, and content.
It is a good time to leave,
Till then, commend us to your gentlest thoughts.

stage.l: They look scurvily upon Fitsgraue, and he upon them.

sp.l: Ugh.

stage.l: The boy in a corner, with his master pocket-Gallant.

sp.l: Hist, master Hist.
Boy? how now?
Look you sir.
Her Chain of Pearl.
I sneaked it away finely.
Active boy, thy masters best revenue, his life and soul
Thou keepest them both together? whip, away,
Fall back, fall belly, I must be maintained,
Hope is no purchase, nor care if I miss her, why I rank
In this design with gallants, there is full cause
Policy invites me to it, it is not for love,
or for her sake alone:
It keeps my state suspectless and unknown.
Their looks run through, and through me, and the stings
Of their Snake hissing whispers pierced my hearing:
They are mad she graced me with one private minute,
Above their fortunes, I have observed them often,
Most spitefully aspected toward my happiness,
Beyond all others: but the cause I know not,
A quiet month the Virgin has enclosed
Unto herself: suitors stand without till then,
In which space cunningly I will wind myself,
Into their Bosoms. I have bethought the shape,
Some credulous Scholar, easily infected
With fashion, time, and humour, unto such
Their deepest thoughts, will like to wanton fishes,
Play above water, and be all parts seen:
For since at me their envy pines I will see
Whether their lives from touch of blame sit free.

stage.l: Enter Primero, the bawd gallant, meeting Mistress

sp.l: Mistress New-cut, welcome, here will be choice of
Gallants for you anon.
Is all clear, may I venture? am I not seen of the
wicked?
Strange absurdity, that you should come into my house
and ask if you be not seen of the wicked, push, I take it unkindly
ifaith, what think you of my house, it is no such common
receptacle.
Forgive me sweet master Primero, I can be content
to have my pleasure as much as another, but I must have a care
of my credit, I would not be seen;
anything else; my husband is
at Sea, and a woman shall have an ill report in this world
let her carry herself never
so secretly: you know it master
Primero: and what choice of Gallants be they? will they be
proper Gentlemen think you?
Nay sure they are as proper as they will be already.
I must have choice you know, I come for no gain, but
for sheer pleasure and affection.
You see your old spy hole yonder, take your stand, please
your own eye, I will work it
so, the Gallants shall present themselves
before you and in the most conspicuous fashion.
That is all I can desire -- till better come? look you.
What mean you Lady?
A trifle sir, to buy your silver Spurs: good sir accept it.
Silver Spurs, a pretty emblem, mark it, all her gifts are
about riding still; the other day she sent me Boot-hose
wrought in silk and gold, now silver spurs; well go thy
ways, thou art as profitable a spirit as ere lighted into my house;
come Ladies come, it is late, to Music, when?
You are best command us: sir, our pimp is grown proud.
To fools, and strangers these are Gentlewomen
of sort, and worship: Knights heirs, great in portions,
Boarded here for their Music,
And oftentimes it has been so cunningly carried,
That I have had two stolen away at once,
And married at Sauoy and proved honest shopkeepers;
And I may safely swear they practised Music:
Their natural at pricksong, a small mist
Will dazzle a fools eye, and that is the world,
So I can thump my hand upon the table,
With an Austere grace and cry 1 2 and 3,
Fret, stamp and curse, foh it will pass well for me?
How now sirrah?
They are coming in sir, and strangers in their company,
Tune apace Ladies, be ready for the Song sirrah?
Nay I beseech you gallants be more inward with this,
Gentleman his parts deserve it,
Whence comes he sir?
Piping hot from the University, he smells of
buttered loaves yet, an excellent scholar, but the arrantest
Ass, for this our Solicitor,
he is a rare fellow five and forty
mile hence, believe that: his friends are of the old fashion,
all in their graves, and now has he the leisure to follow
all new fashions, ply the Brothels, Practise salutes and
Cringes.
O!
Now dear acquaintance,
I will bring you to see fashions.
What house is this sir?
O of great name here Music is professed,
Here sometimes Ladies practise, and the meanest,
Daughters to men of worship,
Whom Gentlemen such as ourselves may visit,
Court, clip and exercise our wits upon,
It is a professed courtesy.
A pretty recreation ifaith.
I seldom saw so few here, you shall have them sometimes
in every corner of the
house, with their Viols betwixt
their legs, and play the sweetest strokes it would even filch your
soul almost out of your bosom.
Pox on it: we spoil ourselves for want of these things
at University?
You have no such natural happiness, let us draw near,
Gentlemen you are all most respectively welcome:
We are bold and insatiate Suitors sir to the breath of
your music, and the dear sight of those Ladies.
And what our poor skill can invite you to,
You are kindly welcome: you must pardon them Gentlemen,
Virgins and bashful, besides new beginners,
It is not a whole month since they were first entered.
Seven year in my knowledge.
They blush at their very lessons, they will not endure,
To hear of a Stop, a Prick, or a Semiquaver,
O out upon you:
La I tell you, you will bear me witness Gentlemen,
If their complaints come to their parents ears,
Their words of Art, I teach them nought but Art.
Why it is most certain.
For all Scholars know, that
Musica est Ars.
O beastly word?
Look to the Ladies, Gentlemen;
Come another?
this a good Interim?
what have you done sir?
why? what have I done,
Saw you their stomachs queasy, and come with such
gross meat?
Why is it not latin sir,
Latin? why then let the next to it be latin too:
Nay I can assure you thus far, I that
never knew the
language have heard so much that Arts,
is latin for Art, and it
may well be too, for there is more art in it nowadays
than ever was!
is it possible? I am sorry then I have followed it so far.
A Scholar call you him,
Music must not jar; the offence is satisfied, come to
the Song; begin sir.

stage.l: The Song, and he keeps time, shows
several humours and moods: the boy in

sp.l: Not a whole month since you were entered Ladies?
None that shall see their cunning will believe it,
It is no affliction Gentlemen?
I care not much ifaith, if I write down to my father
presently, to send up my sister in all haste,
that I may place her
here at this Music school.
'slid it is the fool my cousin, I would not for the value
of three recreations he had seen me here?
How like you your new prize;
Pray give me leave, I have not yet sufficiently admired her
My wits must not stand idle, 'slife he is in a sick trance?
A cheat or two among these mistresses,
Would not be ill bestowed, I affect none,
But for my pray such are their affections,
I know it, how could drabs and cheaters live else,
Then since the world rolls on dissimulation,
I will be the first dissembler.
Prithee love, comfort, choice, my
only wish, in thee
I am confined, deny me anything
a slight chain of pearl,
Nay if it be but slight --
Being denied,
I prize it slight; but given me by my love,
Light shall not be so dear unto my eye;
Mine eye unto the body as the gift,
How have I power to deny this to you,
That command all my fortunes are thy servants,
And thou the Mistress both of them and me.
The truest that ere breathed.
To a Gentleman,
That thus so long and has so sincerely loved you,
As I myself, never was less pity shown.
Why I never was held cruel.
But to me.
Nor to you.
Go to, it has scarred you much,
I am sorry your conceit is so unkind,
To think me so.
When had I other argument,
I have often tendered you my love and service,
And that in no mean fashion:
Yet were you never
that requiteful Mistress,
That gracest me with one favour,
Slight, not so much as such a pretty ring, pox on it,
It has almost broke my heart.
Has took it off, 'sfoot master Bouser,
Nay where a man loves most, there to be scanted.
My Ring, come, come.
What reckon I a Satin gown or two,
If she were wise.
Life my Ring sir, come.
Have you the face ifaith.
Give me my Ring.
prithee hence, by this light you get none of it.
How?
I hold your favours of more pure esteem,
Than to part from them, faith I do,
However you think of me.
Push pray sir,
Hark you, go to, you have lost much by unkindness,
go your ways.
'sfoot.
But yet there is no time past, you may redeem it.
Come, I cannot miss it ifaith; beside the Gentleman
that bestowed it on me swore to me it cost him twenty nobles.
Twenty nobles, pox of twenty nobles,
But you must cost me more, you pretty villain,
Ah you little rogue.
Come, come, I know you are but in jest,
In jest no you shall see.
No way will get it.
As good give it him now, and hope for somewhat.
I rue love made jest.
