Alas there is no conscience in that sir, shall I enter into
bond, and pay money too.
Tut, I must not be betrayed.
Hear me but what I say sir, I do protest I would not be
he that should betray a man, to be Prince of the world.
Mass that is the devil, I thank you heartily, for he is
called prince of the world.
You take me still at worst.
Swear on this sword then, to set spurs to your horse,
not to look back, to give no marks to any passenger.
Marks, why I think you have left me
never a penny sir.
I mean no marks of any.
I understand you sir.
Swear then.
ifaith I do sir:
Away.
I am gone sir, by my troth of a fierce thief he seems to
be a very honest Gentleman.
Why this was well adventured, trim a Gallant:
Now with a courteous and long thirsting eye,
Let me behold my purchase, and try the soundness of my bones
with laughter, how? is not this the chain of pearl I gave to
that perjured harlot, it is, 'sfoot it is, the very chain, o damned
mistress, ha; and this the purse, which not five days before I
sent her filled with fair spur-royals -- heart; the very gold? --
'slife is this no robbery, how many others flew toward heaven,
Which never came half way thither;
but like fire-drakes,
Mounted a little, gave a crack, and fell;
Feigned oaths bound up to sink more deep to hell.
What folded paper is this? death -- it is her hand.
Master Taylbee, you know with what affection I love you,
You do:
I count the world but as my pray to maintain you,
The more dissembling quean you I must tell you,
I have sent you an embroidered purse here with fifty fair spur-royals
in it --
A pox on you for your labour wench:
And I desire you of all loves to keep that chain of pearl from
Master Pursnets sight --
He cannot strumpet, I behold it now, unto thy secret torture:
So fare thee well, but be constant and want nothing.
As long as I have it ifaith? methinks it should have gone so, --
well; what a horrible age do we live in, that a man cannot have
a quean to himself let him but turn his back the best of her
is chipped a way like a Court loaf, that when a man comes himself,
has nothing but bombast; and these are two simple chippings here,
does my boy pick, and I steal, to enrich myself, to keep her, to
maintain him: why this is right the sequence of the world, --
A. L. maintains her, she maintains a Knight, he maintains a
Whore, she maintains a captain. So in like manner, the pocket
keeps my boy, he keeps me, I keep her, she keeps
him, it runs like quicksilver, from one to another; 'sfoot I perceive
I have been the chief upholder of this Gallant all this
while; it appears true, we that pay dearest for
our pasture are ever
likely worse used, 'sfoot he has a Nag can run for nothing,
has his choice, nay and gets by the running of him; -- o fine
world strange devils, and pretty damnable affections.
Lela, ha, ho?
There boy, again, what news there?
Master, pist, master?
How now boy.
I have descried a prize.
Another lad?
The gull, the scholar?
Master Bowser:
Aye, comes along this way:
Without company.
As sure, as he is your own.
Back to thy place boy.
I have the luck today, to rob in safety:
Two precious cowards, whilst I hear him -- stand
You lie, I came forth to go.
Deliver your purse.
It is better in my pocket.
How now, at disputations, seignior fool.
I have so much logic to confute a knave, a thief, a rogue --
Hold, hold, sir, if you be a gentleman hold, let me rise.
Heart it is the courtesy of his scarf unmasked him to me,
Above the lip by chance, I will counterfeit,
Light, because I am a scholar, you think belike that scholars
have no metal in them, but you shall find, --
I have not don with you cousin.
As you are a Gentleman:
As you are a rogue?
Keep on upon your way sir:
You bad me stand?
I have been once down for that:
And then deliver?
Deliver me from you sir -- o pox on it, has wounded
me Eela, ha, ho my horse, my horse boy:
Have you your boy so ready: o thou world,
How art thou muffled in deceitful sons:
There is such a mist of these, and still hath been,
The brightness of true Gentry is scarce seen:
This journey was most happily assigned,
I have found him dross both in his means and mind: what
paper is this he dropped? I will look on it as I go.
A gull call you him, let me always set upon wise men,
they will be afraid of their lives,
they have a feeling of their iniquities,
and knows what it is to die with fighting, 'sfoot
this gull lays on without fear, or wit; how deep is it sayst
thou boy?
By my faith three inches sir.
La, this was long of you, you rogue.
Of me sir.
Forgive me dear boy, my wound ached, and I grew
angry, there is hope of life boy, is there not?
Puh, my life for yours.
A comfortable boy in man's extremes!
I was never so
afraid in my life but the fool would have seen my face, he
had me at such advantage, he might have commanded my
Scarf, I scaped well there it had choked me; my reputation had
been past recovery, yet live I unsuspected,
and still fit for Gallants
choice societies -- but here I vow, if ere I see this Bowser
when he cannot see me either in by-lane, privilege
place, Court, Alley, or come behind him when he is standing,
or take him when he reels from a Tavern late, pissing again
a Cundit, Wall, or Gate, when he is in such a plight and
clear from me, I will do that I am ashamed to speak till then.
Nay read forward, I have found three of your Gallants, like
your bewitching shame merely sophistical, there is your
bawd gallant, your pocket gallant, and your whore gallant.
Master Taylbee.
That is he
I count the world but as my prey, to maintain you?
That is just the phrase and still of them all, to him: they
meet altogether in one effect, and it may well hold too, for
they all jump upon one cause, subands lechery.
What shapes can flattery take, let me entreat you,
Both in the virgins right, and our good hopes
Since your hours are so fortunate, to proceed.
Why he is base that fairs,
until he crown his deed.
See that dissembling devil, that perjured strumpet.
Welcome my souls best wish, -- o out alas, thy arm
bound in a scarf, I shall swoon instantly,
Heart and I will fetch you
again in the same tune,
O my unmatched love, if any spark of life remain,
Look up, my comfort, my delight, my --
O good, o good?
The organ of her voice is tuned
There is hope in women, when their speech returns:
See like the Moon after a black eclipse,
She by degrees recovers her pure light:
How cheers my love?
As one new waked out of a deadly trance,
The fit scarce quiet.
It was terrible for the time, I had much ado to fetch you.
Shrew your fingers,
How came my comfort wounded, speak?
Faith in a fray last night.
In a fray? will you loose your blood so vainly,
Many a poor creature lacks it, tell me how?
What was the quarrel?
Loath to tell you that.
Loath to tell me.
Yet it was my cause of coming.
Why then, must not I know it:
Since you urge it, you shall,
You are a strumpet.
O news abroad sir?
Say you so.
Why you knew that the first night you lay with me.
Nay not to me, only but to the world.
Speak within compass man.
Faith you know none, you sail without.
I have the better skill then.
At my first step into a Tavern room, to spy that
chain of pearl wound on a strangers arm you begged of me.
How, you mistook it sure.
By heaven the very selfsame chain.
O cry you mercy, it is true, I had forgot it, it is Saint Georges
day tomorrow, I lent it to my cousin
only to grace his arm
before his mistress.
Notable cunning.
And is this all now ifaith.
Not, I durst go further.
Why, let me never possess
your love, if you see not
that again a Thursday morning, I take it unkindly ifaith you
should fall out with me for such a trifle.
Better and better.
Come, a kiss and friends.
Away.
By this hand I will spoil your arm if you will not.
More for this than the Devil.
Ye, at your book so hard.
Against my will, are you there Seignior Logic,
A pox of you sir.
Why how now, what has fate sent us here, in the name
of Venus goddess of Cypress.
A freebooters pink sir, three or four inches deep.
No more, that is conscionable ifaith.
Troth I am sorry for it, pray how came it sir?
Faith by a paltry fray, in Colman street.
Come park he would say.
No less than three at once sir, made a Triangle with
their Swords and Daggers, and all opposing me.
And amongst those three, only one hurt you sir.
Ex for ex.
Troth and I will tell you what luck I had too, since I parted
from you last.
What I pray?
The day you offered to ride with me. I wish now I had
had your company, 'sfoot I was set upon in Come park by
three too.
Bah.
Robbed by this light of as much gold and Jewels, as I valued at forty pound,
Sure Saturn is in the fifth house.
I know not that, he may be in the sixth if he will for
me, I am sure they were in my pocket
wheresoever they were:
but I will never refuse a Gentleman's company
again when it is offered
me, I warrant you.
I must remember you, it is Mitre night Ladies.
Mass it is indeed, Friday today, I had quite forgot,
when a woman is busy, how the time runs away.
O you have betrayed us both.
I understand you not.
You have let him see, the chain of Pearl I gave you.
Who him: will you believe me,
By this hand he never saw it.
Upon a strangers arm he swore to me,
Mass that may be, for the truth is ifaith,
I was robbed of it at Come park.
It was that betrayed it.
I would had stayed him,
He was no stranger, he was a thief ifaith,
For thieves will be no strangers.
How shall I excuse it?
Nay I have you fast enough boy, you rogue.
Good sir, I beseech you sir, let me go.
A pickpocket, nay you shall to Newgate luck you:
is this your Boy sir.
How now boy? a monster? thy arm lined fast in another's
pocket, where learnt you that manners; what company
have you kept a-late that you are so transformed into a rogue,
that shape I know not, believe me sir I much wonder at the alteration
of this boy, where he should get this nature: as good
a child to see to, and as virtuous, he has his Creed by heart,
reads me his chapter duly every night;
he will not miss you
one tittle in the nine commandments.
There is ten of them.
I fear he skips over one; thou shalt not steal.
Mass like enough.
Else grace and memory, would quite abash the boy.
Thou graceless imp, ah thou prodigious child, begot at some
eclipse, degenerate rogue. Shame to thy friends, and to thy master
eke: how far digressing from the noble mind of thy brave
Ancestors that lie in Marble, with their coat armours over them.
Had he such friends?
The boy is well descended, though he be a rogue and
has no feeling of it, yet for my sake,
and for my reputations seek
not the blood of the boy, he is near allied to many men of worship
now yet living, a fine old man to his farther, it would kill
his heart ifaith, he would away like a Crysom,
Alas good gentleman.
Ah shameless villain, complainest thou? dost thou want?
No, no, no, no.
Art not well clad, thy hunger well resisted.
Yes, yes, yes, yes,
But thou shalt straight to Bridewell.
Sweet master.
Live upon bread and water, and chap choke.
I beseech your worship.
Come I will be his surety for once:
You shall excuse me indeed sir?
He will mend, he may prove an honest man for all this,
I know gallant Gentlemen now, that have done as much as
this comes to in their youth.
Say you so sir?
And as for Bridewell, that will but make him worse, he
will learn more knavery there in one week, than will furnish
him and his heirs for a hundredth year.
Deliver the boy.
Nay I tell you true Sir, there is none goes in there a
quean, but she comes out an arrant whore I warrant you.
The boy comes not there for a million.
No you had better forgive him by ten parts.
True, but he must not know it comes from me, down
a your knees you rogue, and thank this gentleman has got
your pardon.
O I thank your worship:
A pox on you for a rogue, you put me to my set
speech once a quarter:
Nay gentlemen you quite forget your hour, lead master Bowser

stage.l: Exeunt all but Gold; and Curtisan.

sp.l: Let me go you are a dissembler
How.
Did not you promise me a new gown?
Did I not? yes faith did I, and thou shalt have it, go
sirrah run for a Tailor presently.
Let me see for the contour now; Orange tawny, Peach colour,
what sayst to a Watchet Satin?
O it is the only colour I affect.
A very orient colour, if it please your worships, I
made a gown of it for a Gentlewoman the other day, and it does
passing well upon her.
A Watchet Satin gown.
There your worship left sir.
Laid about Tailor.
Very good Sir.
With four fair Laces.
That will be costly sir.
How you rogue costly, out of the house, you slipshod,
sham-legged, brown bread, penny-skeand rascal.
Nay my sweet love.
Hang him rogue, he is but a Botcher neither, come I will
send thee a fellow worth a hundred of this, if the slave were

stage.l: In the midst of the music, enter one
bringing in a suite of Satin,
knocks at Taylbees door, enter his man.

sp.l: Who knocks.
A Christian: pray is not this master
Taylbees lodging, I was directed hither.
Yes, this is my masters lodging.
Cry you mercy sir. Is he yet stirring.
He is awake, but not yet stirring, for he played away half
his clothes last night
My mistress commends her secrets unto him, and presents
him by me with a new Satin suite here.
Mass that comes happily.
And she hopes the fashion will content him.
There is no doubt to be had of that sir --
your mistress name
I pray? you are much preciously welcome.
I thank you uncommonly sir.
The suite shall be accepted I warrant you sir.
That is all my Mistress desires sir.
Fare you well sir.
Fare you well sir.
This will make my master leap out of bed for joy,
and dance Wigmors galliard in his shirt about the chamber?

stage.l: The Musicke plaies on a while, then enter;
Taylbee his man after trussing him.

sp.l: Came this suite from mistress Cleeueland?
She sent it secretly sir.
A pretty requiteful squall, I like that woman, that can
remember a good turn 3 months after the date, it shows
both a good memory, and a very feeling spirit.
This came fortunately sir, after all your ill luck last night.
I had beastly casting Jack.
O abominable sir, you had the scurviest hand -- the old
Serving-man swooped up all;
I am glad the fortune lighted upon the poor fellow
by my troth, it made his master mad?
Did you mark that sir, I warrant he has the doggedest
master of any poor fellow under the dog sign, I had rather
serve your worship, I will say that
behind your back sir, for nothing,
as indeed I have no standing wages at all, your worship
knows.
O but your vails Jack your vails considered,
when you run too and fro between me and mistresses.
I must confess my vails are able to keep an honest
man go I where I list.
go to then Jack.
But those vails stand with the state of your body sir as
long as you hold up your head, if that droop once, farewell
you, farewell I, farewell all, and droop it will, though all the
candles in Europe should put to their helping hands to it; it is
even as uncertain as playing
now up now down, for if the Bill
rise to above thirty, here is no place for players, so if your
years rise to above forty, there is no room for old lechers.
and that is the reason all rooms are taken up for
young Templers?
you are in the right sir?
peise on it I pawned a good beaver hat to master Frip last night Jack,
I feel the want of it now, -- hark who is that knocks;
Is master Taylbee stirring?
What is your pleasure with him, he walks here in the hall.
Give your worship good morrow,
Welcome honest lad;
A letter from my mistress.
Who is thy mistress?
Mistress new-blocke.
Mistress new-blocke my sincere love how does she?
Faith only ill in the want of your sight.
Alas dear sweet, I have had such business, I protest I
never stood still since I saw her.
She has sent your worship a Beaver hat here, with a band
best in fashion.
How shall I requite this dear soul?
It is not a thing fit for me to tell you sir, for I have three
years to serve yet: your worship knows how I warrant you;
I know the drift of her letter, and for the Beaver, say,
I accept it highly.
O she will be a proud woman of that sir.
And hark thee tell thy mistress as I am a Gentleman,
I will dispatch her out of hand, the first thing I do of my credit,
canst thou remember these words now?
Yes sir as you are a Gentleman you will dispatch her out of
hand the first thing you do.
Aye of my credit.
O of your credit, I thought not of that sir.
Remember that good boy?
Fear it not now sir.
I dreamt tonight Jack, I should have a secret supply out of the City
Your dream crawls out partly well sir, -- what news
there now?
I have an arrant to master Taylbee --
Yonder walks my master;
Mistress Tiffany commends her to your worship and has
sent you your ten pound in gold back again, and says she
cannot furnish you of the same Lawn you desire, till after
all hollantide --
Thank her she would let me understand so much? ha,
ha, -- this wench will live, why this was sent like a workwoman
now, the rest are botchers to her, faith I commend her
cunning, she is a fool, that makes her servant fellow to her
heart, it robs her of respect, dams up all duty, keeps her in
awe even of the slave she keeps.
This takes a wise course I commend her more,
Sends back the gold, I never saw before:
Well women are my best friends ifaith,
Takes lands give me good legs:
Firm back white hand black eye, brown hair,
And add but to these five a comely stature,
Let others live by art and I by nature.
Master Bowser Master Bowser, ha, ha, ho, master Bowser.
Holla:
What not out of thy kennel, Master Bowser.
Master Goldstone, you are an early Gallant sir?
A fair cloak yonder ifaith, -- by my troth abed Master
Bowser, you remember your promise well overnight.
Why what is o'clock sir?
Do you ask that now, why the chimes are spent at Saint Brides.
It is a Gentleman's hour, faith Master Goldstone I will be
ready in a trice.
Away there is no trust to you:
Faith I will come instantly?
Nay choose whether you will or no, by my troth your
cloak shall go before you --
Nay Master Goldstone I have sworn -- do you hear sir:
Away, away, faith I am angry with you, pox, abed now
I am ashamed of it.
Foot my cloak, my cloak Master Goldstone, 'slife what
mean you by this sir you will bring it back
again, I hope, no
not yet, by my troth I care very little for such kind of jesting,
methinks this familiarity now extends a little too far unless
it be a new fashion come forth this morning, secretly yesterday
it would have shown unmannerly, and saucily; I scarce
know yet what to think of it, well there is no great profit in
standing in my shirt, I will on with my clothes, has bound me
to follow the suite, my cloak is a stranger he was made but
yesterday, and I do not love to trust him alone in company.
What may I conjecture of this Goldstone? he has not
only pawned to me this cloak, but
the very Diamond and
Sapphire, which I bestowed upon my new love at Master Primeroes
house; the cloak is new and comes fitly, to do me great
grace at a wedding this morning, to which I was solemnly
invited. I can continue change more than the proudest Gallant
of them all; yet never bestow
penny of myself, my pawns
do so kindly furnish me: but the sight of these jewels is able
to cloy me, did I not preserve my stomach the better for the
wedding dinner, a gift could never
have come in a more patient
hour, nor to be better digested; as she proved false, -- but
I will not fret today nor chafe my blood.
Ha, yonder goes Bowser, the place is fit: -- boy stand
with my horse at Corner, I owe you for a Pink three inches deep
sir?
Take that in part payment; for Come park:
How now, who is this? 'sfoot one of our Gallants,
knocked down like a Calf, is there such a plague of them here
at London, they begin to knock them on the head already:
O Master Bowser, pray send me your hand sir; I am
slain:
Slain and alive? o cruel execution?
What human so savage spirited durst presume,
To strike down satin on two taffetas cut:
Or lift his hand against a Beaver hat.
Some rogue that owes me money, and had no other means
To a wedding dinner: I must be dressed myself methinks.
How why this my cloak, life how came my cloak
hither?
Is it yours sir? Master Goldstone pawned it to me this
morning fresh and sailing and borrowed five pound upon it.
How, pawned it? pray let me hear out this story, come,
and I will lend you to the next barbers surgeons; -- pawned my
cloak?
How now Marmaduke what is the wager;
Nay my care is at end sir, now I am come to the
sight of you? my mistress your cousin entreats you to take part
of a dinner with her at home at her house, and bring what
Gentleman you please to accompany you.
Thank my sweet cuz, I will munch with her say.
I will tell her so.
Marmaduke --
Sir?
Will there be any stock fish thinkst thou?
How sir?
Tell my cuz I have a great appetite to stock fish ifaith --
Master Goldstone I will entreat you to be the gentleman
that shall accompany me.
No? me sir?
You sir.
By my troth concluded, what state bears thy cuz
sirrah?
O a fine Merchants wife, --
Or rather a Merchants fine wife --
Trust me and that is the properer phrase here at London,
and it is as absurd too, to call him fine Merchant, for being
at sea, a man knows not what pickle he is in.
Why true --
Yet my cuz will be served in plate I can tell you, she
has her silver Jugs and her guilt Tankards.
Fie.
Nay you shall see a house dressed up ifaith, you must not
think to tread on the ground when you come there. --
No, how then?
Why upon paths made of fig-frails,
and white blankets cut out in steaks.
Away -- I have thought of a device, where shall we meet
an hour hence.
In Powles.
Agreed.
The broker gallant and the cheating gallant,
Now I have found them all, I so rejoice;
That the redeeming of my cloak I weigh not:
I have spied him.
Pox here is Boucer.
Master Goldstone, my cloak, come where is my cloak sir?
O you are a sure Gentleman; especially if a man stand
in need of you, he may be slain in a morning to breakfast, ere
you vouchsafe to peep out of your lodging.
How?
No less than four Gallants, as I am a gentleman, drew
all upon me at once, and opposed me so spitefully, that I not
only lost your cloak in the fray.
Comes it in there?
But my rich Hangers, sirrah, I think thou hast seem them.
Never ifaith sir.
Those with the two Unicorns, all wrought in Pearl
and gold pox on it it frets me ten times more than the loss of
the paltry cloak; prithee if thou lovest me speak no more
of it, it brings the Unicorns into my mind, and thou wouldst
not think how the conceit grieves me: I will not do thee that
disgrace ifaith, to offer thee any satisfaction, for in my soul I
think thou scornest it thou bearst that mind in my conscience;
I have always said so of thee; fare thee well, when shall I see
thee at my chamber, when?
Every day shortly.
I have fine toys to show thee.
You win my heart then:
The Devil scarce knew what a portion he gave his children,
when he allowed them large impudence to live upon, and so turned
them into the world, surely he gave away the third part of the riches
of his kingdom, revenues are but fools to it; the filed
tongue and the undaunted forehead,
Are mighty patrimonies, wealthier than those
The city sire, or the Court father leaves,
In these behold it, riches oft like slaves
Revolt, they bear their foreheads to their graves,
What soonest grasps advancement, men's great suites
Trips down rich widows, gains repute and name,
Makes way wherever
it comes, bewitches all
Thou impudence, the minion of our days
On whose pale cheeks favour and fortune plays!
Call you these your five Gallants, trust me they are rare fellows
They live on nothing; many cannot live on something,
Here they may take example, -- Suspectless virgin!
How easy had thy Goodness been beguiled
Now only rests, that
as to me they are known,
So to the world their base Arts may be shown.
Art sure thou sawest him receive it boy?
Forty pound in gold as I am a gentleman born,
Thy father gave the Rams head boy?
No you are deceived my mother gave that sir.
what is thy mothers, is thy fathers;
I am sorry it holds in the Rams head, see here he walks,
I was sure he came into Powles, the gold had been yours
master long ere this, but that he wears both his hands in his
pockets:
How unfortunately is my purpose seated, what the devil
should come in his mind to keep in his hands so long, the
biting but of a paltry louse would do me great kindness now.
I knew not how to requite it, will no rascal creature afflict me,
stay, what if I did impudently salute them out, good, boy be ready
boy.
upon the least advantage sir?
You are most devoutly met in Powles sir?
So are you, but I scarce remember you sir.
O I cry you mercy sir, I pray pardon me I fear I have
tendered an offence sir, troth I took you at the first for one
master Dumplin a Norfolke gentleman.
There is no harm done yet sir?
I hope he is there by this time, how now boy, hast it?
No by troth have I not, this labour is lost, it is in the right
pocket, and he kept that hand in sure enough.
Unpractised Gallant, salute me but with one hand, like
a counterfeit soldier, O times and manners? are we grown
beasts, do we salute by halves, are not our limbs at leisure,
where is comely nurture, the Italian kiss, or the French cringe,
with the Polonian waste: are all forgot, then misery follows --
Surely fate forbade it, had he employed but his right hand, I had
had it: -- It must be an everlasting device I think, that procures
both his hands out at once: do you walk sir.
No I stay a little for a Gentleman's coming too.
Farewell then sir, I have forty pound, in gold about me,
which I must presently send down into the country.
Fare you well sir: I wonder Master Goldstone spares
my company so long, it is now about the navel of the day, upon
the belly of noon.

stage.l: Enter Goldst, and his man disguised both.

sp.l: See where he walks, be sure you let off at a twinkling now.
When did I miss you, -- your worship has forgot, you
promised Mistress Newcut your cozen, to dine with her this day.
Mass that was well remembered.
I am bold to salute you sir.
Sir.
Is Mistress New-cut your cousin sir.
Yes, she is a cousin of mine sir.
Then I am a cousin of yours, by the Sisters side.
Let me salute you then, I shall be glad of your farther acquaintance.
I am a bidden guest there too.
Indeed sir?
Faith invited this morning.
Your good company shall be kindly embraced sir.
I walk a turn or two here for a Gentleman, but I
think he will either overtake me, or be before me.
It is very likely sir; there sirrah go to dinner, and about
two wait for me?
Nay let him come between two and three cousin,
for we love to sit long at dinner in the City.
Come sweet cousin,
Nay cousin keep your way cousin,
Good Cousin I will not ifaith cousin.
Why how now sirrah, upon twelve of the clock, and not
the cloth laid yet -- must we needs keep Exchange time still.
I am about it forsooth.
You are about it forsooth; you are still about many things,
but you never do one well,
I am an Ass to keep thee in the house
now my husband is at sea, thou hast no audacity with thee, a
foolish dreaming lad, fitter to be in the garret, than in any place
else, no grace, nor manly behaviour;
when didst thou ever come
to me, but with thy head hanging down, o decheerful
prentice, uncomfortable servant: pray heaven the Gull my cousin
has so much wit left, as to bring master Taylbee along with
him; my comfort, my delight, for that was the chiefest cause I
did invite him, I bad him bring what Gentlemen he pleased to
accompany him, as far as I durst go, why may he not then
make choice of master Taylbee, had he my wit or feeling he
would do it.
Where is my sweet cousin here, does she lack any guess?
Ever such guess as you,
you are welcome cousin.
I am rude Lady.
You are most welcome sir.
There will be a gallant here anon cuz,
He promised faithfully.
Who is it master Taylbee?
Master Taylbee, no master Goldstone.
Master Goldstone; I could think well of that Goldstone,
were it not for one vild trick he has.
What is that Lady?
In jest, he will pawn his punks for suppers.
That is a vild part in him ifaith, if he were my brother.
Pray gentlemen sit awhile, your dinner shall come presently.
ye mistress New-cut, at first give me a trip,
A close bite always asks a secret nip.
My cousin here is a very kind natured soul ifaith, in her humour.
Puh you know her not so well as I cuz, I have often observed
her in all her humours you never
saw her a little waspish I think.
I have ifaith.
Puh, then ye never saw
pretty humour in your life, I can
bring her into it when I list.
Would you could ifaith.
Would I could? by my troth if I were sure thou couldst
keep thy countenance cuz, what a pretty jest have I thought
upon already to entertain time before dinner.
prithee cuz what is it, I love a jest a-life ifaith.
Ah but I am jealous you will not keep your countenance
ifaith.
Why ye shall see a pretty story of a humour.
Faith I will try you for once, you know my cousin will
wonder when she comes in to see the cloth laid
and never a
salt upon the board.
That is true ifaith.
Now will I stand a while out of sight with it, and give her
humour play a little.
Cuz dost thou love me, if thou
wilt ever do any
thing for me, do it.
Marry I build upon you countenance.
Why dost thou think I am an ass cuz?
I would be loath to undertake it else, for if you should
burst out presently, cuz the jest would be spoiled.
Why do not I know that, away, stand close, so, so, mum
cousin? a merry companion ifaith, here will be good sport anon,
-- whilst she comes?
I make you stray long for a bad dinner, here cousin, if
Master Goldstone were come, the meat is
even ready.
Some great business detains him cousin, but he will not be
long now?
Why how now, gods my life, --
Why?
Was ever mistress
so plagued with a shittle-headed servant
why -- Marmaduke.
I come forsooth:
Able to shame me from generation to generation.
Did you call forsooth?
Come hither forsooth -- did you lay this cloth?
Yes forsooth:
Do you use to lay a cloth without a salt, a salt, a salt, a
salt, a salt, a salt.
How many salts would you have, I am sure I set the
best in the house upon the board.
How? cousin: -- sings -- cousin, cousin, did call cuz.
Did you see a salt upon the board when you came in.
Puh.
Come, come, I thought as much, beshrew your singers,
where is it now?
Your cousin yonder.
Why the man is mad.
Cousin, hist cousin.
What say you.
Puh, I call not you, I call my cousin, come forth with
the salt cousin: ha, how, nobody: why was not he that came
in even now your cousin?
My cousin: O my bell salt, O my great bell salt.
The tenor bell salt; o here comes Master Goldstone
now cousin, he may tell us some news of him. Did you not
meet a fellow about door, with a great silver salt under his
arm.
No sure, I met none such.
Pardon me sir, I forgot all this while to bid you welcome.
I shall loath this room forever. Take hence the cloth
you unlucky maple-faced rascal, come you shall dine in my
chamber sir.
No better place lady.
No less than forty pound in fair gold at one lift, the
next shall swoon, and swoon again
till the devil fetch him ere
I set hand to him, heart, nothing vexes me so much but that I
paid the Goldsmith for the change too not an hour before,
had I let it alone in the chain of silver as it was at first, it
might have given me some notice at his departure, 'sfoot I
could fight with a windmill now, sure it was some unlucky villain,
why should he come and salute me wrongfully too mistake
me at noon day, now I think on it in cold blood? It could
not be but an induction to some villainous purpose, well, I shall
meet him -- .
This forty pound came fortunately to redeem my
chain of pearl from mortgage, I would not care how often I
swooned to have such a good caudle to comfort me, gold and
pearl is very restorative. --
See yonder is the rogue I suspect for foul play, I will
walk muffled by him, offer some offence or cause of a quarrel,
only to try his temper, if he be a coward, he is the likelier to be
a rogue, an infallible note.
What a pox ail you sir, would I had been aware of
you.
Sir, speak you to me?
Not I sir, pray keep on your way I have nothing to say to you.
You are a rascal.
You may say your pleasure sir, -- but I hope I go not
like a rascal.
Are you fain to fly to your clothes, because you are
Gallant, why there is no rascal, like your Gallant rascal believe
that.
You have took me at such an hour, faith you may
call even what you please,
nothing will move me.
No, I will make somewhat move you? draw? I suspected
you were a rogue, and you have pursed it up well with a coward?
Who my Patron.
Keep out you rascal.
The guest that did me the kindness in Powles,
Hold as you are a gentleman, you will give me breath sir.
Are you there with me, a vengeance stop you, you
have found breath enough
to run away from me.
I will never
meet this slave hereafter in a morning but I will breath myself
upon him, since I can have no other satisfaction, he shall
save me that forty pound in fence school.
When things are cleanly carried, sign of judgment,
I was the welcomest Gallant to her alive,
After the salt was stolen; then a good dinner,
A fine provoking meal which drew on apace,
The pleasure of a daybed, and I had it:
This here one ring can witness, when I parted,
Who but sweet Master Goldstone, I left her in that trance.
What cannot wit so it be impudent
Device and compass? I would fain know that fellow now,
That would suspect me but for what I am.
He lives not; It is all in the conveyance, what? Thou lookest
not like a beggar, what makest thou on the ground, I have a hand
to help thee up, a fair chain of pearl, surely a merchants wife
gives lucky handsel; they that find pearl may wear it at a
cheap rate, marry my Lady dropped it from her arm for a device
to toll me to her bed, I have seen
as great a matter. -- who be
these? I will be too crafty for you, o monsieur Primero, Seignior
Frip is it you gallants.
Sweet master Goldstone?
every bawd exceeds
me infortunate: master Primero
was robbed of a Carcanet upon monday last, laid the goldsmiths
and found it. I have laid goldsmiths Jeweller, Burnisher Broker,
and the devil and all I think, yet could
never so much as hear
of that chain of pearl, he was a notable thief, he works
close; peace, who be these, ha, let me see, by this light there it
it is back least they see thee; a happy minute, Goldstone what an
age do we breath in, who, that saw him now would think he
were maintained by purses: so, who, that meets me, would think
I were maintained by wenches, as far as I can see it is all one
case, and holds both in one Court, we are both maintained by
the common road way? Keep thou thine
own heart, thou
livest unsuspected, I leese you again now.
But I pray you tell me,
met you no Gentlewomen by the way you came?
Not any what should they be?
Nay I do but ask,
Because a Gentlewoman's glove was found,
Near to the place I met you?
Faith we saw none sir.
good officers, upon suspicion of felony.
Very good sir
What call you the thiefs name you do suspect?
Master Iustinian Goldstone.
Remember, master Goldstone, a terrible world the
whilst, my Masters.
Look you that is he; upon him officers.
I see him not yet, which is he sir.
Why that.
He a thief sir, who that Gentleman in the Satin?
Even he.
Farewell sir, you are a merry Gentleman.
As you will answer it officers, I will bear you out, I will be
your warrant.
Nay if you say so, what is his name then.
Iustinian Goldstone.
Master Iustinian Goldstone, we apprehend you sir upon
suspicion of felony.
Me.
You sir.
I charge you in the Kings name gentlemen to assist us.
Master Taylbee?
The same man sir.
Life what is the news?
Have you forgot Come park?
Come park? no, it is in Kingstone way.
I believe you will find it so.
I not deny it.
Bear witness has confessed.
What have I confessed, pair of coxcombs indubitable?
I was robbed finely of this chain of Pearl there,
And forty fair spur royals.
Did I rob you?
There where I find my goods I may suspect sir.
I dreamt this would be his end.
See how I am wronged Gentlemen:
As I have a soul, I found this chain of pearl,
Not three yards from this place, just when I met you.
Ha, ha!
Yet the law is such, if he but swear it is you, you are gone.
Pox on it, that ere I saw it.
Can you but swear it is he, do but that, and you tickle
him ifaith?
Nay if it come once to swearing let me alone:
Say and hold, he called my Jewels counterfeit, and so
cheated the poor wench of them:
Come bring him away, come?
It will call my state in question!
I think what is got by theft doth
never prosper,
Now lost my chain of pearl -- come master Goldstone, let us go
this mine ifaith,
The chain of pearl?
By my troth it is mine;
By my troth much good do it you sir?
I am glad in my soul sir --
Deliver your weapons,
How?
You are apprehended upon suspicion of felony?
Felony? what is that?
Was it you ifaith, sir all this while, that did me that
kindness to ease both my pockets at Come park:
I sir? pray gentlemen draw near, let us talk among
ourselves, stand apart Scoundrel; --
must every gentleman be
upbraided in public that flies out now and then upon necessity,
to be Themes for peddlers and weavers? this should not be,
it was never seen among
the Romans; nor read we of it in the
time of Brute: are we more Brutish now? did I list to blab, do
not I know your course of life master Taylbee to be as base as
the basest, maintained by me, by him by all of us and a second
hand from mistresses, I have their letters here to show?
Why should you be so violent to strip naked
Another's Reputation, to the world knowing
your own so leprous,
Beside this chain of pearl and those spur royals came to you
falsely for she broke her faith, and made her soul a strumpet
with her body, when she sent those;
they were ever justly mine?
Pray what moves you sir, why should you shake your head,
you are clear, sure I should know you sir, pray are not you sometimes
a pander, and oftener a bawd sir, have I
never Sinned in your
banqueting boxes, your bowers and towers? you slave, that
keeps fornication upon the tops of trees, the very Birds cannot
engender in quiet for you, why rogue, that goes in good
clothes made out of wenches cast gowns.
Nothing goes so near my heart as that?
Do you shake your slaves noddle?
And here is a rascal looked away too, (saving the presence
of master Goldstone;) a filthy slimy lousy nittical broker,
pricked up in pawns from the hat band to the shoestring --
a necessary hook to hand gentlemen's suites on it in the Air,
least they should grow musty with long lying? which his
pawns seldom are guilty of, a fellow of several scents and
Steams; French, Dutch, Italian, English, and therefore his lice
must needs be mongrels. why Bill money?
I am sorry to hear this among you, you have all deceived
me, truly I took you for other Spirits, you must pardon me
henceforward, I have a reputation to look to, I must be no
more seen in your companies;
Nay, nay, nay, nay, master Goldstone, you must not scape
so ifaith, one word before you go sir,
Pray dispatch then, I would not for half my revenues
ifaith now, that any gallants should pass by in the
mean time, and find me in your companies, nay as quick as
you can sir.
You did not take away master Bowcers cloak the other
morning, pawned it to me and borrowed five pound upon it;
Ha?
It was not you neither that finely cheated my little
Novice at master Primeroes house, of a Diamond and Sapphire,
and swore they were counterfeit, both glass, mere glass
as you were a right gentleman;
'slife, why were we strangers all this while? 'sfoot I
perceive we are all natural Brothers?
a pox on us all are we
found ifaith?
A cheater?
A thief, a lecher, a bawd and a Broker?
What mean they to be so merry, I am afraid they
laugh at us and make fools of us.
Push, leave it to me -- how now: who would you speak withal?
Speak withal? have we waited all this while for a suspected
thief?
How? you are scarce awake yet I think,
look well, does any appear like a thief in this company away
you slaves, you stand loitering, when you should look to
the common wealth? you catch knaves apace now, do you not?
they may walk by your nose, you rascals?
Sweet Master Goldstone.
You lacked spirit in your company, till I came among
you: here be five of us, let us but glue together, why now the
world should not come between us.
If we be true among ourselves.
Why true; we cannot lack to be rich; for we cannot
lack riches, nor can our wenches want, nor we want wenches.
Let me alone to furnish you with them.
And me.
There is one care past: and as for the Knights daughter,
Our chiefest business, and least thought upon.
That is true ifaith.
How shall we agree for her.
With as much ease as for the rest: tomorrow brings
the night, let us all appear in the best shape
we may; troth is, we
have need of it, and when amongst us five she makes election,
as one she shall choose.
True, she cannot choose.
That one so fortunate amongst us five,
Shall bear himself more portly, live regarded,
Keep house, and be a countenance to the rest.
Admiral.
For instance, put case yourself after some robbery done
Were pursued hardly; why there were your shelter,
You know your Sanctuary: nay say you were taken,
His letter to the Justice will strike it dead,
It is policy to receive one for the head.
Let us hug thee Goldstone.
What have I begot?
What Sir?
I must plot for you all, it likes me rarely.
prithee what is it sir?
It would strike Fitsgraue pale,
And make the other Suitors appear blanks.
For our united mysteries.
What if we five presented our full shapes
In a Strange gallant, and conceited mask?
In a mask, your thoughts and mine were twins.
So the device were, subtle nothing like it.
Some Poet must assist us.
Poet? you will take the direct line to have us staged? why
what lacks Bowser, are you too well, too safe, an absolute
scholar, easy to be wrought, no danger in the operation.
But have you so much interest?
What in Bowser? why my least word commands him:
Then no man fitter.
And there is Master Frip too, can furnish us of masking suites enough.
Upon sufficient pawn I think I can sir:
Pawn? I owe, here take my chain: pawns among brothers?
we shall thrive? but we must still expect one rogue in
five, and think us happy too.
Last man we spoke on, Master Bowser.
Little master Bowser, sweet master Bowser welcome ifaith?
Are your fathers dead, gentlemen, you are so merry.
By my troth a good jest, did not I commend his wit to
you gentlemen, hark sirrah Rafe Bowser, cousin Bowser ifaith?
there is a kind of portion in town, a girl of 15 hundred, whom
we all powerfully affect, and determine
to present our parts to
her in a Mask.
In a Mask!
Right sir, now a little of thy brain for a device to present
us firm, which we shall
never be able to do ourselves
thou knowest that; and with a kind of speech wherein thou
mayst express what gallants are, bravely;
Puh, how can I express them otherwise but bravely: now
for a Mercury and all were fitted.
Could not a boy supply it?
Why none better.
I have a boy shall put down all the Mercuries in the town,
He will play a Mercury naturally, at his fingers end ifaith.
Why then we are suited; for torch-bearers and shield-boys,
those are always the writers properties; you are not troubled
with them.
Come my little Bowser; do it finely now, to the life.
I warrant you gentlemen.
Hist; give me a little touch above the rest if you can
possible, for I mean to present this chain of pearl to her.
Now I know that let me strive to fit you.
Come forth you wary private -- why spring strumpet
have we found your close haunts, your private watchtowers,
and your subtle means.
How then?
You can steal secretly hither, you mystical quean
you, at twilight, twitter-lights, you have a privilege from your
hat forsooth, to walk without a man, and no suspicion,
But we poor gentlewomen that go in Tires
Have no such liberty we cannot do thus,
Custom grants that to you that is shame in us.
Have you done yet?
You broke the back of one husband already and now the
others dead with grief at sea, with your secret expenses,
close stealths cunning filches, and continued banquets in corners;
then forsooth you must have your milk baths to white
you, your rose-leaves to sweeten you, your bean-flour bags,
to sleek you, and make you soft, smooth, and delicate, for lascivious
entertainment.
So, and you think all this while you dance like a thief
in a mist, you are safe, nobody
can find you; pray were not you
a Felmongers daughter at first, that run away with a new
Courtier for the love of Gentlewomen's clothes, and bought
the fashion at a dear rate, with the loss of your name and credit,
why what are all of you, but rustical insides, and city flesh,
the blood of yeomen, and the bum of gentlewomen --
What shall we suffer a changeable forepart to out-tongue
us, take that.
Murder, murder --
How now? why Ladies, a retreat, come, you have shown
your spirits sufficiently, you are all land captains, and so they
shall find that come in your quarters, but have you the law
free now to fight and scratch among yourselves and let your
Gallants run away with us.
How?
Good.
Sweet master Bowser.
Another?
Why then I perceive you know nothing: why they are
in the way of marriage:
A knights daughter here in town makes her election among
them this night.
This night?
This very night, and they all present themselves in a
mask before her, know you not this?
O traitor Master Goldstone.
Perjured Master Taylbee.
Without soul?
She will chase him.
You have more cause to join, and play the grounds of
friendship amongst yourselves,
than rashly run division; I could
tell you a means to pleasure you:
Good master Bowser.
But that you are women and are hardly secret.
We vow it seriously?
You should be all there in presence,
See all, hear all, and yet not they perceive you.
So that --
Sweet master Bowser, -- I
I can stand you in stead,
For I frame the device, --
If ever --
Will you do it -- harke you --
Content.
And I will make one.
And I another,
We will mar the match,
When that good news came of my husbands death,
Goldstone promised me marriage,
and Swear to me.
I will bring his oaths in question.
So will I:
Agree among yourselves, for shame.
Are we resolved?
In this who would not fain.
Friends all for my part,
Here is my lip for mine?
Round let it go,
All wrath thus quenched,
And I conclude it so.
How all events strike even with my wishes,
Their own invention
damns them, -- now Gentlemen?
stands your assistance firm?
Why it is our own case,
I am sorry you should doubt.
We will furnish you?
Are these our Gallants?
Are our Gallants these?
Here be five shields sir?
Finished already, that is well? I will see thy master shortly,
I am satisfied.
Prithee let us see master Fitsgraue,
I have blazed them,
What is this;
Faugh, you should be a gallant too, for you are
no university Scholar?
Look this is Pursnets, the device, a purse wide open,
and the mouth downward. The word
Allumis ecce crumenis.
What is that?
One that lives out of other men's pockets,
That is right?
Here is Goldstones three silver dice,
They run hie, two sinks and a quarter?
They are hie men fit for his purpose; -- The word,
Nay he will cheat his own brother,
nay his own father ifaith?
So much the word imports -- Master Primero,
Pox what says he now?
The device, an unvalued pearl, hid in a cave.
The word, Occulos vendit honores,
What is that?
One that sells maidenheads by wholesale;
Excellently proper?
Master Frip?
That pythagoricall rascal, in a gentleman's suite today,
in a knights tomorrow:
The device for him; a Cuckoo sitting on a tree? The
word, En auis ex auibus;
one bird made of many; for you
know as the Sparrow hatches the Cuckoo, so the Gentleman
feathers the Broker?
Let me admire thee, master Fitsgraue?
They will scorn gentlemen: and to assist them the better,
Pursnets boy that little precious pickpocket, has a compendious
speech in latin, and like a Mercury presents their
dispositions more liberally:
Never were
poor gallants so abused?
Hang them, their counterfeits, no honest spirit will pity them.
This is my Crown,
So good men smile I dread no rascals frown.
Away, bestow yourselves secretly, overhead, this is the place
appointed for the rehearsal, to practise their behaviours.
We are vanished.
Master Bowser,
Well said ifaith, off with your cloaks gallants, let us
fall roundly to our business:
Is the boy perfect?
That is my credit sir, I warrant you?
If our little Mercury should be out, we should scarce
be known what we are.
I have took a course for that, fear it not sir; look
you first here be your Shields:
Aye Where be our Shields?
which is mine?
Which is mine master Bowcer? this?
I pray be contained a little gentlemen, they will come all
time enough to you, I warrant:
This Frip is grown so violent;
Yours to begin withal sir?
well said master Bowcer, first the Device, a fair purse wide
open, the mouth downward, the word
Allienis ecce crumenis?
What is that prithee?
Your bounty pours itself forth to all men.
And so it does ifaith? that is all my fault, bountiful?
Master Goldstone here is yours sir, three silver Dice, the
word, Fratremque Patremque?
And what is that?
Fortune of my side?
Well said little Bowcer ifaith?
What say you to me sir?
For the device A Candle in a corner; the word,
Consumptio, Victus:
The meaning of that sir?
My light is yet in darkness, till I enjoy her, right sir?
Now mine sir?
The Device an unvalued pearl hid in a Cave.
Ah ha sirs?
The word, Occultos vendit honores:
Very good I warrant,
A black man is a pearl in a fair Ladies eye,
I said it was some such thing;
My turn must needs come now; am I fitted Master Bowcer?
Trust to me, your device here is a Cuckoo sitting on a tree,
The Welsh Lidger, good.
The word, En auis ex Auibus.
Aye marry sir.
Why do you know what it is sir.
No by my troth not yet sir.
O, I keep one tune, I recant not.
I am like the Cuckoo in that indeed, where I love I hold.
Did I not promise you I would fit you.
They are all very well done ifaith, and very Scholar-like,
though I say it before thy face little Bowcer, but I would not have
thee proud of it now: come if this be performed well.
Who the Boy, he has performed deeper matters than this.
Aye a pox on him, I think was in my pocket now, if
truth were known.
I caught him once in mine.
Suppose the shields are presented, then you begin boy.
I representing Mercury, am a Pickpocket, and have his
part at my fingers ends, Page I am to that great and secret
thief, magno illo et Secreto Latroni.
There you make your honour sir.
At Latroni.
You have it sir.
Latroni, that is mine.
He confesses the Thief is his.
Remember boy, you point Latroni to me.
To you Master, proceed.
These four are his companions, the one a notable cheater,
that will cozen his own father.
Master Goldstone.
Let me alone master Boucer, I can take
mine own turn.
Why.
Peace.
The second an notorious lecher maintained by harlots
cuius virtus consumptio corpus.
That is I master Bowcer.
There you remember your honour sir.
Virgineos ob lucrum vendens honores.
It sounds very well ifaith.
splendidus, is no otherwise
but a Broker, these feathers are not his own,
sed auis ex Auibus;
all which to be nothing but truth, will appear by
the event.
ifaith here is all now Gentlemen.
Short and pithy.
A good boy ifaith and a pregnant.
I dare put trust in the Boy sir; forget not sirrah at any
hand to point that same Latroni to me.
I warrant you master.
Come Gentlemen the time beckons us away.
Aye, furnish Gentlemen, furnish.
Hark one word master Boucer, what is the same Latroni,
I have a good mind to that word ifaith.
Latroni? why Sheriff of the Sheer.
ifaith? and I have striven some shears in my days.
Now gentlemen are you satisfied and pleased?
Never more amply:
Amongst us now falls that desired lot,
For we shall blast five rivals with one plot.

stage.l: Enter the Virgin between two ancient gentlemen.

sp.l: Grave gentlemen in whose approved bosoms,
My deceased father did repose much faith
You are dearly welcome: pray sir, command music,
See nothing want to beautify this night,
That holds my election in her peaceful arms,
Feasts, Music, Hymns, those sweet celestial swarms.
May you be blessed in this election.
That content, may meet perfection.
Sound Lute, Bandora, Gittern,
Viol, Virginals and Cittern!
Voices spring and lift aloud,
Her name that makes the Music proud:
this night perfection,
makes her election:
Follow, follow follow, follow round,
Look you to that, nay you to that, nay you to that:
anon, you will be found, anon you will be found, anon you will be found.

stage.l: Enter the mask, thus ordered, A torch-bearer, a shield-boy,
then a masker, so throughout, then the shield-boys fall at one end,
the torch-bearers at the other; the maskers in the middle, the torch-bearers
are the five gentlemen: the shield-boys the whores in boys
apparel: the maskers the five Gallants, they bow to her she rises
and showers the like, they dance but first deliver the shields up; she

sp.l: Alienis ecce crumenis.
Fratremque, Patremque.
Consumptio victus.
Occultos vendit honores.
A Cuckoo: en auis ex auibus.
Are you all as the speech and shields display you?
We shall prove so.

stage.l: They going to dance, each unclasps his weapon from his side,
and gives them to the torch-bearers. Katherine seems distrustful,
but then Fitsgraue whispers to her and falls back.
At the end of which all making an honour, Frip presents her

sp.l: The very chain of Pearl was filched from me.
Hold stop the boy there.
Will none lay hands on him.
How now.
Alas I am but a broker, it was pawned to me in my shop.
Ha, Fitsgraue?
Peamont and the rest.
Where is Boucer?
Here.
We are all betrayed.
Betrayed; you are new forth to betrayed, you have not
so much worth: nay struggle not with the net, you are caught
for this world.
Would we were out.
It was I framed your device: do you see it was I;
The whole assembly has took notice of it,
That you are a gallant cheater,
So much the pawning of my cloak contains;
You base thief, think of Come park and tell me that
you are a hired Smokster, here is her letter,
In which we are certified
that you are a Bawd.
The broker has confessed it.
So has the boy.
That boy will be hanged, he stole the chain at first and
has thus long maintained his masters Gallantry.
All which we here present like captive slaves,
Waiting that doom which their presumption craves.
How easily may our suspectless sex,
With fair appearing shadows be deluded:
Dear sir, you have the work so well begun.
That took from you small glory would be won.
Since it is your pleasure to refer to me,
The doom of thief; I have provided so:
They shall not altogether loose their cost;
See I have brought wives for them.
Heart, the strumpets -- out, out.
Having assumed out of their impudence,
The shape of shield-boys.
To heap full confusion.
Rather confine us to strict chastity.
A mere impossible task then to wed these:
Whom we loath worse than the foulest disease.
O grant them their requests.
The doom is past,
So since your aim was marriage:
Either embrace it in these Courtesans,
Or have your base acts, and felonious lives
Proclaimed to the indignation of the law,
Which will provide a public punishment:
As for the boy, and that infectious Bawd,
We put forth those to whipping.
Whipping? you find not that
in the statute to whip satin.
Away with him.
Since all our shifts are discovered, as far as I can see it is
our best course to marry them:
we will make them get our livings.
He says true.
You see how we are threatened, by my troth wenches
be ruled by me, let us marry them if
it be but to plague them; for
when we have husbands we are under covert baron, and may
lie with whom we list; I have tried
that in my the other husbands
days.
A match.
I will be no more deferred, come, when do you join:
These forced marriages do never
come to good.
How can they, when they come to such as you?
They often prove the ruin of great houses,
Nor Virgin do I in this seek to entice:
All glory to myself; these Gentlemen,
To whome I am bound
to love for kind assistance,
Had great affinity in the plot with me.
To them I give my thanks: myself to thee,
Thrice worthy Fitsgraue.
I have all my wishes.
And I presume there is none but those can frown,
Whose envy is like the rushes we tread down.
